Lack enough support: The claim of 80 journalists being killed in Mexico in the last decade lacks enough support as different sources provide varying numbers, with some confirming only 24 deaths directly related to their work as journalists.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that all 80 deaths mentioned by the speaker are work-related, without considering the possibility of other motives or circumstances.
Understate: The claim may understate the dangers faced by journalists in Mexico by not acknowledging the higher number of unconfirmed motive deaths mentioned by the Committee to Protect Journalists.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation for the claim, as the head of Reporters Without Borders' Latin America desk mentioned that the count of 80 deaths includes journalists whose deaths were not proved as work-related.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that there have been cases of American journalists being killed in Mexico in connection with their jobs, as mentioned by the Committee to Protect Journalists.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by relying on nonprofit organizations that gather data on journalist deaths in Mexico, which may have conflicting or incomplete information.
Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the situation in Mexico by presenting the number of journalist deaths without clarifying the proportion of those deaths that are directly related to their work.
